bestBHT.bht: After three sorrowing days, they find Him still in Jerusalem, not gazing on its architecture, but in the temple, in some one of the enclosures around it, where the rabbins taught their scholars. They were seeking Him everywhere, the only thing worth while now was finding the lost boy.

Henry Alford: 45. seeking him everywhere] as they went back, all the way.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: After three sorrowing days, they find Him still in Jerusalem, not gazing on its architecture, or surveying its forms of busy life, but in the temple.
Not the 'sanctuary' (as in :-), to which only the priests had access, but in some one of the enclosures around it.
Where the rabbins, or 'doctors,' taught their scholars.
Marvin Vincent: Seeking him [αναζητουντες] . All the way as they went. Force of ajna, as above.
Archibald T. Robertson: Seeking for him (αναζητουντες αυτον). Present participle of the same verb. This was all that was worth while now, finding the lost boy.
John Gill: They turned back again to Jerusalem, seeking him." (7 words)
At Jerusalem, in the streets and broad places of it." (10 words)
A figure of the church and ordinances, where souls look for, and inquire after their beloved." (17 words)

bhtAttempts.bht: After three sorrowing days, they find Him still in Jerusalem, not gazing on its architecture, but in the temple, in some one of the enclosures around it, where the rabbins taught their scholars. They were seeking Him everywhere, the only thing worth while now was finding the lost boy.

After three sorrowing days, they find Him still in Jerusalem, not gazing on its architecture, or surveying its forms of busy life, but in the temple, where the rabbins, or 'doctors,' taught their scholars. They had turned back again to Jerusalem, seeking Him everywhere, all the way as they went, for this was all that was worth while now, finding the lost boy. In this moment, we see a figure of the church and ordinances, where souls look for, and inquire after their beloved.

After three sorrowing days, they find Him still in Jerusalem, not gazing on its architecture, or surveying its forms of busy life, but in the temple, where the rabbins, or 'doctors,' taught their scholars. They had turned back again to Jerusalem, seeking Him everywhere, all the way as they went, for this was all that was worth while now, finding the lost boy. In this moment, we see a figure of the church and ordinances, where souls look for, and inquire after their beloved.

After three days of searching, they find Jesus still in Jerusalem, not taking in the sights or busyness, but in the temple where the religious teachers held their lessons. With determination, they had returned to Jerusalem, searching for Him all along the way. In this story, we see a powerful depiction of the church and its longing for its beloved Savior. Just as the parents diligently sought their lost son, so too do souls in the church seek and inquire after Jesus.

After three sorrowing days, they find Him still in Jerusalem, not gazing on its architecture, or surveying its forms of busy life, but in the temple where the rabbins, or 'doctors,' taught their scholars. Seeking Him everywhere, all the way as they went, for this was all that was worth while now, finding the lost boy. In this moment, we see a figure of the church and ordinances, where souls look for, and inquire after their beloved.
